statement: E. Nearest Opposite Paritytime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given an array $$$a$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ integers. In one move, you can jump from the position $$$i$$$ to the position $$$i - a_i$$$ (if $$$1 \\le i - a_i$$$) or to the position $$$i + a_i$$$ (if $$$i + a_i \\le n$$$).For each position $$$i$$$ from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$ you want to know the minimum the number of moves required to reach any position $$$j$$$ such that $$$a_j$$$ has the opposite parity from $$$a_i$$$ (i.e. if $$$a_i$$$ is odd then $$$a_j$$$ has to be even and vice versa).InputThe first line of the input contains one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$) â€” the number of elements in $$$a$$$.The second line of the input contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le a_i \\le n$$$), where $$$a_i$$$ is the $$$i$$$-th element of $$$a$$$.OutputPrint $$$n$$$ integers $$$d_1, d_2, \\dots, d_n$$$, where $$$d_i$$$ is the minimum the number of moves required to reach any position $$$j$$$ such that $$$a_j$$$ has the opposite parity from $$$a_i$$$ (i.e. if $$$a_i$$$ is odd then $$$a_j$$$ has to be even and vice versa) or-1if it is impossible to reach such a position.ExampleInput10 4 5 7 6 7 5 4 4 6 4Output1 1 1 2 -1 1 1 3 1 1

You are given an array of $n$ integers. You can move from position $i$ to position $i - a_i$ (if $1 \le i - a_i$) or to position $i + a_i$ (if $i + a_i \le n$).

For each position $i$ from 1 to $n$, find the minimum number of moves required to reach a position $j$ where the value at $a_j$ has the opposite parity (even if $a_i$ is odd, and vice versa). If it's impossible to reach such a position, output -1.

You are given a list of numbers.  For each number in the list, find the fewest steps it takes to reach another number in the list with a different parity (odd or even). If it's impossible, output -1.  You can move to a neighboring position based on the value of the current number.
